title: `IssuingDistributionPoint.hash` fails for valid inputs
body:
`IssuingDistributionPoint` objects become unusable in hashed collections when `full_name` is set. The constructor accepts a `list[GeneralName]`, but `__hash__` later tries to hash that list directly, causing an immediate `TypeError`.


```python
from cryptography.x509.extensions import IssuingDistributionPoint
from cryptography.x509.general_name import DNSName

idp = IssuingDistributionPoint(
    full_name=[DNSName("example.com")],
    relative_name=None,
    only_contains_user_certs=False,
    only_contains_ca_certs=False,
    only_some_reasons=None,
    indirect_crl=False,
    only_contains_attribute_certs=False,
)

hash(idp)
```

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/data/src/test.py", line 14, in <module>
    hash(idp)
  File "/home/py312/lib/python3.12/site-packages/cryptography/x509/extensions.py", line 2114, in __hash__
    return hash(
           ^^^^^
TypeError: unhashable type: 'list'
```

**Expected**: Hash succeeds (so the object can be used in sets, dict keys, etc.). 
`full_name` is [documented](https://cryptography.io/en/latest/x509/reference/#cryptography.x509.IssuingDistributionPoint.full_name) to accept a list of `GeneralName` objects, so the input above is valid.  Converting list-like fields to tuples inside `__hash__` should resolve the inconsistency.

## Versions tested on:
46.0.3

## Operating systems tested on:
Linux
